description: This course provides an introduction to the quantitative methods used in characterizing and engineering biomolecular properties and cellular behavior, focusing primarily on receptor-mediated phenomena. The thermodynamics and kinetics of protein/ligand binding are covered, with an emphasis on experimental techniques for measuring molecular parameters such as equilibrium affinities, kinetic rate constants, and diffusion coefficients. Approaches for probing and altering these molecular properties of proteins are also described, including site-directed mutagenesis, directed evolution, rational design, and covalent modification. Equilibrium, kinetic, and transport models are used to elucidate the relationships between the aforementioned molecular parameters and cellular processes such as ligand/receptor binding and trafficking, cell adhesion and motility, signal transduction, and gene regulation.
name: BIOMOLEC & CELLULAR ENG

values.comments:
This course introduces the quantitative methods used in characterizing and
engineering biomolecular properties and cellular behavior, focusing primarily on
receptor-mediated phenomena. The thermodynamics and kinetics of protein/ligand
binding are covered, with an emphasis on experimental techniques for measuring
molecular parameters such as equilibrium affinities, kinetic rate constants, and diffusion
coefficients. Approaches for probing and altering these molecular properties of proteins
are also described, including site-directed mutagenesis, directed evolution, rational
design, and covalent modification. Equilibrium, kinetic, and transport models are used to
elucidate the relationships between the aforementioned molecular parameters and cellular
processes such as ligand/receptor binding and trafficking, cell adhesion and motility,
signal transduction, and gene regulation.
Students felt that lectures went fast and you had to make an effort to keep with the
pace of the class. As a student puts it, “You learn a lot, but you are expected to pay close
attention in lecture and work hard.” Students reported learning a lot of material in the
course. A student reported, “The heavy emphasis on biomolecular interactions in the first
part of the course provided an excellent foundation for the rest of the course.” Students
also enjoyed the “good integration of papers into what we were learning and connecting
the course from start to finish.” Another student comments about the pace of the course,
“The course builds well, had a good number of problem sets and outside-of-class work
(not too much/little) and fair exams.”
Sakar was commended on being a “very good professor.” Students enjoyed the
format of the class where you are “able to get student participation & have some
discussion about the topics to help us understand them.” Students wished there were
more classes at Penn that taught as much as this class.
This class is meant for graduate students in Bioengineering. Advanced
undergraduate students also could take it, but most stated it was very difficult and
experience in chemical engineering was basically necessary. Students felt that this class
was very difficult but rewarding. Students wished that more class time were dedicated to
problem solving, as the problem sets were very difficult on material that went beyond
what was taught in class. Students thought the exams were tough but fair, “exams were
kind of on long side, but questions themselves were fair.”
This review is based on the 7 student reviews that were submitted.
